review_blob: Obtained a can via a trade and was surprised to find it to be a very decent golden lager. Nothing terribly exciting but nonetheless a satisfying and refreshing beer. Im not a fan of most domestic macro lagers so was pleased to see that this product was definitely a step up from that grouping of beers. If this were available in my geographic area, Id be happy to purchase a 6-pack.

My first Tired Hands product - acquired in a fortunate trade. Unusually strong and very pleasant aroma. I love mosaic hops and this product really satisfies that love. The only negative is that its not currently distributed in or near my area - and probably wont be in the near future. Maybe I need to take a trip to eastern PA this coming spring.

Picked up a Tall Boy can while traveling in CT even though I was somewhat wary of the 11% ABV noted on the label of this Double IPA. As it turns out, my concern was quickly shown to be unwarranted. Poured the 16 oz. into a glass and failed to find any significant harshness or booziness in the body or taste - overall, a very well balanced higher alcohol IPA. My only regret is that I purchased only 1 can and its not distributed in my home state so future enjoyment depends on my next CT trip.
beer_name: Pioneer the New Frontier - Double California Style IPA

review_blob: Im certainly not used to aggressive beers under the Samuel Adams label so this one surprised me. I enjoy bitterness in a beer and this one truly provided plenty to satisfy me. I can see why it might be considered too bitter or too aggressive but I found it to be a solid Double IPA. Not a Heady Topper but a fine product nonetheless. Im not sure its a big advancement from Rebel Rouser but thats not a negative as RR is another SA product that I have enjoyed since its introduction.

Ive grown to really enjoy IPLs as much as IPAs. Brewmaster Jack does nothing to diminish my new preference with this excellent version featuring the Mosaic hop. Picked up a 22 oz. bottle on a trip to MA and wish I had picked up more than one. Taste seems stronger than the aroma and thats a positive to me. One of the hoppier IPLs Ive come across but not excessively bitter. Ill be a repeat purchaser on my next visit to MA.
beer_name: Brewmaster Jack Hop Essence Series Mosaic

review_blob: Never heard of this brewery but happily received a can in a trade. Very surprised with the product. Light citrusy body with medium bitterness. Had a lot of body for a session IPA. If this were available in my area, Id be heading out go buy a 6-pack.

Very clever brand name but, more importantly, a very solid Double IPA. First product Ive tasted from this brewery and regret I only picked up 1 can. I personally enjoy bitterness and this product more than satisfied my taste buds in this regard. Not sold in my area but Ill definitely be looking forward to finding it again when next in CT.

beer_brewer_name: Uncle Billys Brew & Que Smokehouse & Brewery
review_blob: 16 oz. can acquired in a trade. One of the better craft lagers Ive tasted in recent years. Crisp and tasty, mildly hoppy, well carbonated and possesses a lot of body for a 4.7% ABV. Never heard of Uncle Billys but the brewery has my respect based on this product. Hopefully Ill land another can at some future date

Purchased a single bottle at Julios. First bottled product Ive seen from this brewery and first of their products Ive tasted. If this is a representative example of the quality of their brews, Id consider the brewery to have made a very promising start in the bottling world and look forward to trying other of their products. My only regret is not purchasing a 6-pack.

Poured from an attractive 12 oz. can. Ive consumed a lot of Session Ales in recent months and this was among the better ones. I wondered how Harpoon would develop this product along side its long-time regular IPA. Hoped it wouldnt just be a watered down version of the regular IPA - and it definitely wasnt. Plenty of hop flavor - more of the IPA flavor I prefer than many others Ive tried. Also glad to see that Harpoon is canning it - should be an excellent product to combine with outside activities.

Finally obtained a 6-pack of hard-to-find cans thanks to a Fathers Day gift from my son. I havent been disappointed - between this product and Captains Daughter, Grey Sail rates very high on my list of IPA brewers. I had previously sampled and enjoyed this product at the brewery in 2014 and was delighted to hear it was being canned. However, the cans have been difficult to locate on my occasional trips to RI. Im enjoying these 6 and hope to be able to find more in the future.

Picked up a 6-pack of cans from Julios in MA to take back home as Ive been very pleased with previous Newburyport product purchases. Glad I did as this one did not disappoint. One of the tastiest Session style IPAs that Ive tried to date. Did not taste like a watered down IPA as some have done. Definitely worth a repeat purchase on my next trip to Julios.

I had never heard of the Glass Bottom brewery until I saw this product and also an ESB from the brewery at a western MA package store. Brought this bottle to a sharing event and it was rated as one of the best sampled that night. Fortunately I bought 2 bottles and enjoyed the second one at home. Definitely worth a repeat purchase when Im in the area again.

By far, my favorite brew from Back East. I pretty much agree with the Commercial DeScription" - i.e., solid malt foundation and loads of wholesome hop goodness. Took me a while to find a can of this brew but Im glad I kept looking for it.

Not a big fan of many Blonde Ales but thought this one had more body and taste than others Ive tried. Nothing special - just an easy drinking product for some who might want a break from the hoppier brews. Obtained this can in a trade and know nothing about the brewery or its products but would be happy to have this beer again if the opportunity arises.

Purchased a 4-pack and glad I did so. Zeppelin is a fine example of the Hefeweizen style. Banana flavor is definitely present but not dominating. Citrus and hops also blend into the flavor mix. Light on the palate - not too filling and could be a fine session beer despite the 5.5% ABV.

beer_brewer_name: The Prodigal Brewery at Misty Mountain Farm
review_blob: 22 oz. bottle purchased in Nashua, NH. First time Id seen it available in a bottle. Solid example of a Munich Style Lager. No surprise as the brewer has a known reputation for lagers. I realize its a very small brewery at this time but hope this product could become available in a smaller size - it would be an excellent summer refreshment.

Tree House has done it again - undoubtedly the best Pale Ale Ive had in many years. Wish Tree House distributed in NH but the trip to MA is well worth it for products like this one. Also glad that they are canning - my favorite form of packaging.

22 oz. bottle - a solid product from a local brewery. The second Henniker product Ive tried and felt positive about. Hard to compete with the many breweries offering higher ABV IPAs but this product definitely competes. Im hoping it will soon become available in 6 or 4 packs of 12/16 oz. bottles.

16 oz. can acquired in a trade. Apparently Im not a fan of canned nitro products. I generally enjoy a variety of Saranac products but this one was not a winner to my taste. Saranac has done better Brown Ales (non-nitro) in prior years.

Another unexpected find while traveling in PA. Unfortunately only brought 1 can home with me. This was a top level Pale Ale from a brewery previously unknown to me. I usually prefer an IPA and discovered this brewery makes an excellent one. However, this Pale Ale does not rank any lower than the IPA in most, if not all, important characteristics.

Obtained a can while traveling in PA but didnt open it until returning to NH. Wish I had obtained a 6-pack as I found it to be one of the best new (to me) IPAs tasted during the past year or so. Very hoppy but I love hops and the resulting aroma as well as flavor was outstanding. Ill look for it on my next trip to PA.

I admire Baxters brewing skills and enjoy most all of their products. However, this one is a rare exception. I enjoy session IPAs but apparently not when mixed with green tea powder. I realize they were being creative but the flavor profile just didnt work for me. Fortunately, their non-session Stowaway is an excellent IPA and a regular in my refrigerator.

beer_brewer_name: Pretty Things Beer and Ale Project
review_blob: Bomber bottle purchased at Julios. Not what I was expecting in a Bock style but very enjoyable nonetheless. I was initially very surprised at the manner in which the malt dominated but that didnt detract from my overall impression of the product. I have no problem with purchasing it again although would prefer 12 oz. bottles to bombers..

12 oz. bottle - very disappointing. I would never have guessed that this was intended to be an English IPA style. Ive enjoyed a few other Olde Burnside products but this one had no taste appeal at all and no resemblance to other English style IPAs Ive tasted.

Body is somewhat watery and overall taste a bit too sweet for what I would expect in a session IPA. Ive tried a number of Session IPAs and this is not one of my favorites. As far as Berkshire IPAs are concerned, I much prefer their Lost Sailor brand.

This American Pale Ale is probably playing second fiddle to Stonefaces outstanding IPA in their product mix but nonetheless I thought it was an excellent example of its style. Difficult to find in local stores but well worth the effort of tracking it down. This young brewery has done quite a job with its initial products.

beer_brewer_name: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
review_blob: Nice to see this Oktoberfest in a 16 oz. can for the first time. Im a big fan of Oktoberfests so have sampled a lot of them this fall. Id rate this as one of the best. Considering this product and the Czech Style Pilsner, Moat Mountain has been a real winner with its Lagers

beer_brewer_name: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
review_blob: Good to see Moat Mountain putting a solid Helles Lager in a 16 oz. can. Purchased a 4-pack at Brewtopia in Keene, NH and am very glad I did. While Lagers arent necessarily my favorite style, this product is one that Ill happily repurchase. Refreshing and flavorful with no obvious flaws.
beer_name: Moat Mountain Hell Yes! Helles Lager

review_blob: Very disappointing. Ive had 2 bottles purchased from different stores and both had the similar bland taste of a weak pale ale. Couldnt tell the age of the bottles as I couldnt find any dating information on them. Although the ale is not of a drain pour status, I cant find any reason to purchase it again. If nothing else, I do like the label design - simple and straight forward.

Enjoyed several cans fresh from the brewery. Comes across as a typical seasonal marzen with no unusually strong or weak points. Very drinkable for summer or fall. Purchased a 4-pack based on my initial tasting,
beer_name: Grey Sail Autumn Winds Fest Beer

review_blob: Attracted to purchase a bottle due to its appealing label. and not sorry I did so. Flavor had more lasting background smoke than I had expected but enjoyed it nonetheless. Overall, for a lager fan, a good session beer for the summer months or any occasion.

12 oz. bottle with stated ABV of 7.0 but no bottling date that could be found. Apparently no longer an Imperial IPA but also obviously not a Session IPA. Overall, quite tasty and one of the better Ellicottville products that Ive tried.- worthy of a repeat purchase.

The first and only beer Ive tried from this brewery. Now available in an attractive 16 oz. can. Can says that it is a "West Coast inspired IPA" and i think that is a good deScription of the product. Not as bitter as some true West Coast Style IPAs but also not as malty as many UK styles. Overall, a decent product for this young brewery. .

12 oz. can - another in a seemingly endless array of new session IPAs in the marketplace - fortunately, many, including this one, are quite good - not my favorite style of IPA but nonetheless very drinkable and I wouldnt hesitate to purchase it again

Gift bottle from a friend who obtained it at the brewery. Very fresh and sparkling - nice white head gives it additional appeal. I wish this would be part of their year-round portfolio but agree that its particularly appropriate as a summer seasonal. As pale ales go, I rate this one highly and would purchase a 6-pack if it were available in NH. Ommegang hasnt made it here yet

Newly packaged in a 12 oz. can. Hops make their presence known very quickly. More bitter than I had expected and not the flavor profile I would anticipate from such an outpouring of hops. With so many excellent IPAs in the market these days, I dont anticipate purchasing this one again.

My first and only canned beer from the brewers at Blue Hills and it was an enjoyable one. I wondered if the 8.0% ABV would be a problem but that wasnt the case at all. Like some other raters, I question whether this truly fits in the IPA category but, whatever the case, Ill buy it again and this time Ill get a 6-pack of the cans.
beer_name: Blue Hills Quarter Mile Double IPA

review_blob: Strong and pleasing aroma - citrus, banana, piney, etc. Taste follows up in the same vein. I didnt expect it to be so hoppy but am not at all disappointed in the results. The alcohol is noticeable but not a negative. Although Im not necessarily a big fan of the style, I will be repurchasing this product in the near future.

Very disappointed with this local product. Lacking in body and overly carbonated. Didnt taste like an IPA to me and ranks as one of the poorer IPAs Ive purchased. There was no dating on the can so I cant determine if it may have been out of date but it was purchased within 10 miles of the brewery at a major beer store. Doubt that Ill try this one again.
beer_name: Westfield River Charlie in the Rye

review_blob: It appears that Baxter can brew a very nice Lager as well as their usual Ales. I found this to be a refreshing and tasty alternative to my usual diet of IPAs and it definitely warrants future purchases.

Received a can of Red Beards from a friend in Michigan. Id never heard of Latitude 42 before but, after enjoying the contents of the can, now have a great respect for their brewing capability. The red ale/IPA combination seems rather unique to me and very well done by the brewer. Unfortunately, Latitude 42 apparently has very limited distribution and certainly none in New England - otherwise, Id be headed to the store to pick up a 6-pack.
beer_name: Latitude 42 Red Beards India Red Ale

review_blob: Probably the best Imperial IPA Ive tasted. Unusually strong citrus aroma that follows through into the taste. I was initially concerned about the 11.1% ABV but its well hidden - dangerously so in some respects. Glad I purchased a 4-pack but wouldnt drink too many at one sitting. Will definitely purchase again.

Picked up a 22 oz. bottle while traveling through CT. Nice to see another Doppelbock from a New England brewer - and a decent product at that. Quite hoppy for the style but well balanced overall. The 7.5% ABV is not particularly noticeable and it was no problem drinking the whole bottle at one sitting. Hope its still available when I next visit CT. .
beer_name: Two Roads Henrys Farm Double Bock

review_blob: Acquired a can at an informal tasting. My first pineapple beer and, to my surprise, I drank the whole can. Its appearance wasnt particularly appealing - very little head made it look more like fruit juice. It did not have a strong pineapple aroma or taste but, nonetheless, its lightness made it quite drinkable. Doubt that Ill buy it again but enjoyed the opportunity to try it. Much better than the watermelon beers Ive tasted.

Currently enjoying the last of a recently purchased 6-pack of 16 oz. tall boys while hoping that this isnt just a seasonal beer for Narragansett as Id like to purchase another in the near future. Best I can say is that it does a good job of meeting the Commercial DeScription set forth by the brewer. Easy drinking with the taste Id expect from this type of Pilsner. Despite its 5.2% ABV, it drinks in many ways like a session beer. Narragansett has a winner with this one.

I luckily managed to obtain a can of Boat in a trade with a NJ enthusiast. He had much to be enthusiastic about as this was one of the best new (to me) beers Ive tasted this year. Nothing great about its appearance but the aroma and taste more than make up for that slight defect. If this were available in my general area, it would be my choice when desiring a session ale - even more so than Founders All Day. Hope this brewery has expansion plans.

Purchased a single bottle and was so pleased and surprised that I returned and bought a few 6-packs. An unusually hoppy pilsner that appeals to an IPA fan like myself. Grapefruit and tropical hops dominate the aroma and taste, Lots of taste with an ABV below 5%. Ive tried most of the Peak Organic bottled beers and have to rate this one as the best yet.

Picked this up in Wells, ME on a recent trip. One of the best among the many new rye beers coming into the market in recent years. Wish it were more than a seasonal as I love the mix of spicy rye with plenty of hops that hit my taste buds from the very first pour. Glad I purchased a 6-pack rather than just an individual bottle - it was a gamble that paid off for me..

A retro beer found at State Line Liquors. Never had the original but this one stands up quite well on its own. Hops are present but certainly not dominant. Moderately carbonated - crisp, clean and overall refreshing. I dont know whether this is intended to appeal to macro fans, craft fans or both but I thought it was quite a decent product that Id purchase again if its ever distributed closer to my area.
